text: Welcome everybody.
I like that. Uh so my name is Jace. I'm
uh what is what is my title now? Uh
senior user advocate for Perforce. and
I'm here to do a presentation about
leveling up from either an indie studio
who has Perforce set up but isn't
utilizing it to its full potential yet
or someone who's working as more of a
junior or intermediate developer and
they want to start to work their way up
to being in more senior positions
understanding the workflow better how to
maintain quality code things like that
so for this talk I'm assuming that you
already understand the basics of
Perforce if you
you're welcome to hang out. Uh but some
of it might seem a little confusing at
first if you don't. Uh cool. So the
agenda for today, uh first going to talk
a little bit about some best practices
for your as well as how you set up your
streams and mic is cutting in and out.
Uh as well as how you set up your
streams and then we're going to look at
uh the folder structure for the projects
as well and a little bit about P4
shelves. And then we're going to spend
most of the time talking about code
review using P4 code review to set up
pre and postsubmit code reviews or or
art asset reviews. Uh and then at the
end if we have time I'm going to spend a
little bit of time talking about some
cost-saving tips for a cloud server.
So with that let's get into it. did want
to let you know that uh I'll show this
QR code at the end as well, but various

information if you have follow-up

All right. So uh the main thing I want
to drive home here when it comes to
working in streams and branches and if
you come from a git background this is
the biggest mental shift to make and
that is that it the best practice is to
all work in the same stream as much as
possible. So everybody working in the
same branch as much as possible. If you
think about Epic Games when they're
making Fortnite all of them submit
directly into the master branch. They
all submit straight into main and then
they have some other systems for
integrating changes as they're preparing
for releases. Like that's where they'll
use streams, but they actually all work
in the same place. The idea is that we
want find problems early so we can fix
problems early rather than doing months
of development on a side feature and
then you have the horrible time of
trying to integrate that with everything
else. So
what are streams? Why are they useful?
If you're not using streams, if you're
still using classic depots, also called
local depots, uh, now's the time to
change your ways. Uh, switch to streams.
There's just a lot of very powerful
features that you can get when you're
using streams, as well as making things
easier for your users. So, what are
streams? A stream is a branch, except
when it's not. Uh, and that in a second
here. Uh, but you could think of these
just like branches if you're used to
that concept. Also, a stream defines a
workspace view. So, this means that you
can define which parts of the project
are actually part of your workspace. And
you can define that in a stream so that
when a user comes and just picks that
stream to work in, they get those files
rather than every single user having to
decide that for themselves.
Stream force merging rules. So you can
see here that we have these up and down
arrows where these release streams are
set to only allow you to merge down to
main while from development you can go
up and down. They help to enforce those
relationships but if you need to break
those rules you can. you do have that
power.
And then uh streams have superpowers and
that is that they can do things like
importing from other depots, from other
streams, uh doing sparse streams so that
you can make task streams when you need
to um very quickly, very efficiently and
without taking up as much space. And
then we also have virtual streams which
are these ones at the bottom which I
want to talk about in just a little bit.
So, starting off with streams, this is
my recommended stream setup when you're
getting started. That's it. Just one
mainline stream. Everybody works in
that. Great. If you get to a point where
you want to separate a more stable
working version of your project from the
work in progress, then simplest way is
to just make one development stream
underneath your main stream. And so,
everybody works here in development. And
then periodically when the game is
working or when the animation project is
in a stable state, you copy it up into
main so that at any point someone say
they need to do a demo to an investor or
they need to do QA or something like
that, they have a stable working version
in Maine. And it's okay if you break
stuff a little bit in development until
you move stuff up into Maine.
So work is done in the devstream and
then copied up into main when it's
stable for QA or demos or whatever it
is.
Then you can also make release streams.
So a release stream comes off of main
usually. And this is to say yeah this is
our version one. Uh so this is assuming
you're not doing uh well you can do this
with rolling release. That's kind of how
Epic does it with Fortnite. Um, but the
idea is that you have this release here
and then let's say we make another
release. Now, we can put that one over
here. And this means that if we ever
need to go back and fix bugs in those
individual releases, we're able to still
go back, get that state, make those
changes, and then merge that down into
mainline. So, if that applies to you,
release streams can be very useful for
that. Uh, and then we have my favorite
feature, which is virtual streams. So
remember when I said a stream is a
branch except when it's not. A virtual
stream is a child of another stream. So
here it's the development stream and
then we have these virtual streams. When
you're in those virtual streams, you're
actually still in the same branch as
development. So you're actually it's
just like you're working in development,
but you're able to filter down a smaller
view of that. So here's an what this
looks like. So I have these three
virtual streams over here and you can
see I have this Blender dcc folder and
import meshes. And now I switch to a
different virtual stream. I have the
Unreal project, the engine and the
imports. I switch to a different or now
I switch to the the main and I have
everything. I have the project, all of
my dcc folders, my engine folder, all of
my imports. And you can see I can loop
back around. Now I'm just being the
audio artist. So I only have one folder
inside of dcc and just my music and
sound effects, but all of us are working
in the same stream on the same files. We
just get filtered views because my sound
artists don't need everything else,
right? My 3D artists don't need
everything else. So, this allows you to
more efficiently allow people to work on
just the files they need, but you don't
have to merge later because they're all
actually working in that same branch in
that same stream.
All right, let's talk about folder
structure a little bit. So, I've heard
this called the Epic native folder
structure. I've also heard it called
folder structure. And basically it's
just that your engine directory and your
project directory should be side by
side. They should be siblings of each
other. Uh not not inside of each other,
not inside extra subfolders. So right in
your root you have your engine if you're
customizing the engine. If you're not,
don't worry about it. Uh but then have a
project folder and inside of there is
your U project and content and plugins
and all of that.
Now, what I recommend is also adding a
folder for your dcc tools. So, this is
where you can have your Maya, Photoshop,
Blender, Marvelous Designer,
whatever it is, substance, whatever
you're using in a dcc folder, organized
however you want. Could be organized by
uh which character, which prop it is, or
it could be organized by department,
whatever works for you. And then to have
an imports folder. Uh you could also
call it a raw assets folder. And this is
where you would put things like your FBX
exports, your Olympics, your uh PGs of
your textures, that sort of stuff.
Now, by having all of this in one place,
as you saw before with those virtual
streams, it allows us to give each
department just the files they need. Or
you could even make separate virtual
streams for every single employee if you
wanted to. every single team member
could have their own custom virtual
stream if you wanted. Uh so you have a
lot of flexibility by just having a very
simple structure here and then
customizing with virtual streams.
Okay, now let's get to the part where
we're going to talk about code review.
So first of all, who here is familiar
with shelving in P4?
Okay, good. We have a decent number. So
for those who are not, let me show you

to make a change to this camera, move it

and I'll compile and save. Now, you're

I could just open up my revision and

come in here, and I'll see in P4V, I
have my file that's been modified.
Instead of submitting it, I can shove
it. And shelving is kind of thought of
like stashing, but it also puts it on
the server, which means that other
people can access it. So here I'm
shelving it, giving a description, and
now you see it's made a numbered change
list with shelved files inside of it. So
now I'm going to switch to different
user. So let me uh go here. So now I'm a
different user. I put it in dark mode so
you can tell. Different user. And in my
pending change lists tab, if I check
this one that says show only change list
with shelved files and remove the user
filter, I can see that other users
shelved files. And then I can come and
unshove those into my own workspace so
that I could review them or check them
before they're actually submitted. So
everyone else isn't getting this. Only
people who go to that shelf and unshelf
those files. So, uh, you'll see now it's
in my default change list because I've
unsheld that. And then I can open up the
project
and give Unreal a second to load. Uh,
here we are. And now if I go and check
out that blueprint,
I can see that that uh in the viewport I
can see that that value here has been
changed to the the closer camera. It's
set to 300 now instead of 400. So, this
is kind of the manual way that you can
do code reviews is by shelving
something, telling someone else, "Hey, I
shelved this. It's on change list number
five or number 863, whatever it is."
They can unshove that change, check it
out, and tell you if it's good or not,
right? You could even just use it to
like send secret messages to each other,
except it's not secret because
everything's, you know, saved in
perforce. Okay, so now how can we do
that better? And this is where we use
Helix Swarm, which is now called P4 code
review. Uh, so if you ever hear code
review, it means swarm. Code review is
just the new name. So it's simpler, just
says what it does.
So within Swarm, and this is free, by
the way. Code review is free. You can
download it. It just extends your
Perforce server and it adds a um
basically a review functionality kind of
like pull requests if you're familiar
with that in git workflows.
And you can set up two different types
of reviews. We can do pre-commit reviews
which are kind of like what we saw where
it's shelved first and reviewed before
it gets submitted. And then we also have
postcommit reviews which is where it
gets submitted, everyone can see it but
we still want to review it after the
fact. So with pre-commit reviews, uh, we
review the shelves before they're
submitted.
This ensures that the codebase remains
stable and that someone doesn't make
some breaking change that then everybody
else gets and everyone's in trouble.
Now,
uh, you can integrate it with automated
tests and automated builds, which I
highly recommend. We'll cover that a
little bit later today. And then, uh,
generally it produces higher quality
code. However, it can be a bottleneck if
your review process is slow. If you
don't have enough reviewers, this can
slow you down a little bit, right?
Because you're not submitting directly.
You need to get it approved first. So,
there's kind of the trade-off.
This though is especially good for code
changes, for essential functionality
blueprints like gameplay that's going to
affect many other things in the game,
uh, and plugins as well. On the other
hand, we have post commit reviews. With
these, we submit it. It goes into the
depot into the stream and then you
review after the fact. It's fast because
you just get to submit right away and
review later.
You can also create reviews anytime
later on if you want to. You could go
back and say, "Hey, you know what? This
thing that was submitted a month ago,
let's make a review for it. Let's let's
actually check that and decide what we
want to do."
Um, it however uh doesn't give you the
ability to test things first, right? You
just submit them and they're in there.
So again, it could break things. Uh, and
if you do find a problem, it can be more

changes to work around it or something
like that. But it's a good fit for art
teams. So if you think about a character
design or something like that changes
that's generally not going to break a
lot of things in the rest of the game
for people and we might review it and
adjust it but that's okay to do later.
So we can see both use cases have

Um, next is consider your storage volume
types. So, SSD is fastest, but it's also
the most expensive, right? So, if you're
uh storing everything in SSD, as your
project grows, it can end up being
pretty expensive in the cloud. So um SSD
because it's fast and especially because
it's fast at random read write you
definitely want your database so your
metadata and your logs you all want
those to be stored on SSD. So generally
what we do and the the server deployment
package I mentioned does this where
you'll mount three separate volumes to
your instance. You'll have one volume
that's for metadata which is the
database. you have another volume that's
for logs and you'll have a third volume
that's for the depot data or the file
data itself and that's the one that's
going to be huge. So keep your metadata
and your logs on SSD, but those are
relatively small, right? There's like a
few kilobytes per version, per file in
your depot. So they're they're quite
small.
Then you can use a spinning disc. So
like on AWS, this is the difference
between GP2 or GP3 and then ST1 is what
they call it. Uh but Azure, Google, all
the cloud providers have something
similar. So spinning disc hard drive is
generally pretty good at linear
throughput but it's not very fast at
random readr. So for putting your file
data on here hard drive can save you a
good chunk of money because it's usually
about half the price of the same amount
of storage in a state drive.
Uh and then the third thing is S3 or
object storage. So S3 is much slower
than the other two. Uh it's also much
cheaper. So uh it is possible in Helix
core or P4 I should say. Uh in P4 you
can uh configure your depot to use S3 on
the back end. However for performance I
think you might notice a difference
there. But if you use it for archive
depots, which is a feature in P4 where
you can archive files to a different
location that can be cheaper or that you
could snapshot store somewhere else, you
could use S3 to archive things away so
that you free up space on your main
drive where you have all the files uh
and store those in S3 for a much cheaper
price.
All right. And then egress costs, right?
This is for anyone who's worked with
servers in the cloud. This is probably
where you ended up paying more money
than you expected is that all the cloud
providers they it's free to put data
into them and every single bite of data
you get out they charge you money for.
So
yeah, every time you sync guest you're
getting charged money for that, right?
Sometimes they'll have a certain amount
they give you for free, but then over
that it can cost money. Where I've
especially seen this cost people a lot
of money is if they have a build like an
a build automation that wipes the

single time it does a build. That can
really quickly add up because you're
doing that full egress cost of your
whole project every single time a build
or a test is triggered. Uh so that's one
thing to to consider.
And often times just using a P4 proxy is
enough to solve this problem. So if you
have your server in the cloud and then
you set up a P proxy server that's on
premise in your office or somewhere else
that people can access
and basically the proxy server connects
to the main server and then the users
connect to that proxy server instead of
connecting to the main server. So when
they're setting up P4V or their
integration, they would instead point to
the address of the proxy, not to the
actual server. And then whoever requests
a file first, that file gets cached on
the proxy server. And then anyone else
who requests that same file, it'll just
download straight from that proxy
server. So you'll get the files a lot
faster, and you won't get charged egress
more than once per file, per per file
that gets downloaded because it's being
cached. So, um, when we did Project
Titan last year, if any of you are
familiar with that, we had 3,000 people
from around the world. To keep that
infrastructure simple, we had a main
commit server that was based in London
on AWS. So, was AWS and London was the
commit server. And then also on AWS, we
had proxy servers that we had I think
one in where was it Seoul or was it
Australia? I forget. we had somewhere
kind of in this time zone. We had one
that was uh like US West Coast, one US
East Coast and that people could that
closest proxy to them and even that
helped improve performance because using
their you know home internet or their
business internet they were able to
connect to that proxy but then that
proxy is using AWS's own network to
communicate back to that master server.
And so it has much more of a direct
line, has better performance. So proxies
can be super useful and they're really,
really easy because you don't need to
back up a proxy. You could delete your

Doesn't require a lot of extra setup. So
